Although relations between unions and ETV station management are much
more harmonious than they were a few years ago, it would be well in a report
of this nature to review some of the earlier problems encountered, and handled,
by this service,
As became obvious in sometimes heated discussions with various tele¬
vision station and television department directors concerned, this area was
extremely sensitive. Many operations, particularly in certain areas of the
South, had no union problems, and were fearful that the NAEB's concern, and
the securing of Mr, Novik*s services, might cause various unions to move
into areas with which they had not previously concerned themselves. However,
the long experience and skill of Mr. Novik soon convinced these individuals
that this would not occur; and it did not,
Mr, Novik, at the outset, pointed out what he believed to be a serious
oversight in various areas where fund drives and community committees and
organizations were being set up. In some, labor was not represented at all.
In most, labor was not adequately represented in a manner to give it a pro¬
prietary interest, as a part of a worthwhile educational and community project
intended to benefit labor as well as all others.
This policy was generally changed through Mr. Novik's guidance and
influence. Top labor executives were enlisted as supporters of ETV.
